info.title: SUSE Best Practices Strategy and Plan
info.subtitle: Internal Only

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: In every organization, a lot of hidden IT knowledge and experience exists. This is also the case for SUSE, no matter which product you are looking at. Our Consultants, Sales Engineers, Supporters and also Partners work with our customers on a daily basis to implement, strengthen and fine-tune our solutions, to find the best options how to install third party software on our operating system, or to get the most out of our customer’s infrastructure.

For every product and solution, there are subject matter experts that have profound know-how and skills. Many proof of concepts and customer projects have been conducted. And many of them are at least partly documented. But this kind of information is normally "buried" on a personal laptop, probably on a team server, but generally not publicly available for our colleagues, partners or customers. Also, many Technical Information Documents (TIDs) are already written and somewhere on the webpage published, but hard to find.

sect1.title: Mission
sect1.para: The purpose of the SUSE Best Practices is to change this situation, to make existing knowledge and experience available to a broader audience, and to promote it via a recognizable series of documents.

sect1.title: Vision
sect1.para: With the SUSE Best Practices, we aim to introduce a new series of documents that provides reliable technical information and establishes a new “Go-To” source for the usage and implementation of SUSE products and solutions, also in combination with third party software and hardware, similar to the famous IBM Redbooks (http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/).

Our goal is to make the SUSE Best Practices so prominent that at a certain stage volunteers knock at our door to contribute, and feel honored if we pick their proposed topics for our SUSE Best Practices papers.

sect1.title: What is a SUSE Best Practices
sect1.para: In contrast to the SUSE product documentation which mainly guides through SUSE software installation and usage, the series of SUSE Best Practices papers provides installation and implementation experiences.

This means a SUSE Best Practices paper describes a technical scenario / solution that is not covered by the general and extensive SUSE product documentation. Such a scenario can also include third party software and implementations (partly) done by partners.

While the SUSE product documentation is usually delivered in parallel with a new product, the SUSE Best Practices usually will not adhere to newly launched products, but to products already introduced to and established in the market.
Usually the scenario /solution has already been conducted in a real-life scenario at a customer's site. It can include – but is not limited to:

listitem.para: the installation of 3rd party software on top of a SUSE product
the implementation of a multi-part solution

sect1.para: Depending from the complexity of the topic, the SUSE Best Practices might differ heavily regarding their length. Typically a SUSE Best Practices paper should be between 5 and 30 pages in length.

sect1.title: Target Audience
sect1.para: The SUSE Best Practices target mainly system administrators that have to set-up and implement the technical solution in their companies.

sect1.title: Prerequisites for a SUSE Best Practices
sect1.para: The main purpose for a SUSE Best Practices is not to add work to the Documentation team, but to make knowledge that exists in other departments easily accessible for a broader audience.
Thus, the main content for a SUSE Best Practices paper is not delivered by the SUSE documentation team, but it usually comes from:

listitem.para: and in limited occasions also from Engineering

sect1.para: Minimum 80 percent of a proposed or requested topic already need to be available in written form. Before starting with a new project, subject matter experts who worked together with a partner or customer on the implementation of the topic need to be defined, and they need to be committed to work on the paper together with the documentation team. All papers are written in English only.

sect1.title: Contribution of Partners and Customers
sect1.para: Partners and Customers can also request a SUSE Best Practices, and participate in the creation of a paper. Same requirements apply as for internal requestors.

sect1.title: How does the SUSE Documentation Team support
sect1.para: The SUSE documentation team is coordinating all requests for topics and updates. What’s more, the team

listitem.para: helps with finalizing the content where needed via face-to-face and phone interviews and email conversations
correct wording and fine-tuning of the content where needed
ports the content into the formal "layout" of SUSE documents and rewrites the content in DocBookXML
Publishes the final paper on a SUSE public webpage / portal
Promotes the paper via several channels

sect1.para: For writing the documents, the SUSE documentation team uses the official SUSE documentation workflow:

DocBookXML: The documentation team writes all content to be published in DocBook XML. It is based on the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) and defines the content in a semantic way through elements like in HTML. This makes changes and updates easier. In addition, the SUSE Best Practices use the same look-and-feel as the SUSE product documentation.

DocBook Authoring and Publishing Suite (DAPS): DAPS is a command-line tool the SUSE documentation team uses to generate output formats from the XML sources. SUSE Best Practices will usually be provided as single HTML, PDF and ePub. DAPS also allows to implement a modular structure for a collection of papers related to a specific topic. It allows to run some other tasks related to writing and editing, such as spell checker and the SUSE documentation style checker.

Style: The style of SUSE Best Practices should lean on the official style guidelines and existing stylesheets. However, they do not necessarily need to fulfill the guidelines by 100 percent. The language might be more narrative. The layout differs from a usual article. The &sbp; layout will be structured as follows:
title page, contains
title
subtitle
name of the series &sbp;
author(s) details (full name, title, company)
SUSE logo
if needed, partner company logo
second page, contains
abstract of content
table of content
content body
license information

Git: Git is the main version control system for the SUSE product documentation in general, GitHub is used as a hosting server for the sources. For the &sbp;, we also use GitHub to host the sources, to enable for collaboration with contributors spread over different locations. Initially, we will work with public repositories (see also ).

sect1.title: What the Documentation Team does NOT do for SUSE Best Practices
sect1.para: To emphasize it again, the SUSE Documentation team is not delivering or writing the general content for a SUSE Best Practices. The documentation team will not test any described scenario or implementation, or validate the provided content, as it can not reproduce the scenarios.

For the same reasons, the documentation team is notresponsible for delivering the content for updates of a SUSE Best Practices paper. SUSE Best Practices are provided in English. The documentation team does not care for translation in any other language.

sect1.title: Updates
sect1.para: The content for updates of a SUSE Best Practices generally has to come from the original content deliverer, or from another subject matter expert familiar with the topic, defined in advance.

Based on the availability of information for the topic, the documentation team decides if a SUSE Best Practices will be updated or not. Also, the documentation team decides about removing a published paper from the official portal when the information seems to be outdated, and no subject matter expert volunteers to update the existing content.

sect1.title: How to request a SUSE Best Practices
sect1.para:
A SUSE Best Practices paper has to be officially requested via an entry in
FATE
Bugzilla

The entry has to contain a working title a description of the required topic the name(s) of the subject matter expert(s) the attachment of any existing documents. Only in exceptional cases, e.g. where partners or customers are involved without access to FATE or Bugzilla, we accept requests via an email to Meike.Chabowski@suse.com.

sect1.title: License
sect1.para: Usually, all SUSE documentation is published under an open document license, such as http://www.gnu.org/licenses/fdl.html the GNU Free Documentation License, or the Creative Commons http://creativecommons.org/

This is also the case for the SUSE Best Practices. However, we reserve the right to change the copyright of a SUSE Best Practices to a proprietary license in cases where a key contributor has valid reasons to require this, or where we see the exigency to do so to protect SUSE´s business. In the latter case, the paper will be published under SUSE Copyright.

sect1.title: Recognition of authors
sect1.para: SUSE does not pay an author or contributor for the delivery of content for a paper. However, the efforts for contribution to a &sbp; should be recognized with the following activities:

listitem.para: Key content providers for &sbp; will be highlighted as authors of the published document. On the paper, there will be published their full name, job title, and company.
If a paper is written in co-authorship with another company, the logo of the company will also be printed on the title page of the &sbp; paper.
Key contributors to a &sbp; will receive a SUSE or openSUSE branded limited edition merchandise item.

sect1.title: Incentives for collaboration
sect1.para: The main writers of a SUSE Best Practices will receive a special (limited) SUSE branded merchandise item as acknowledgment for their efforts. These items can be but are not limited to:
In a first step, we will give away a one meter plush Geekos.

sect1.title: Distribution and Availability of &sbp;
sect1.para: SUSE Best Practices papers will be published on an official SUSE Website (currently this is ). They will be made available publicly to everyone interested in reading the papers. SUSE will reserve the right to give limited access to particular papers as a value add only to registered customers, via the SUSE Customer Center. We plan to develop and implement a Portal for the &sbp;, where in future all papers of this series will be posted. Details are work in progress.

sect1.title: Promotion of &sbp;
sect1.para: SUSE Best Practices will be promoted via different Social Media Channels (Twitter, Facebook, Google+, SUSE Blogs, etc.). A subset of papers will also be used for broader Marketing purposes, such as email or online campaigns.

sect1.title: Open Items
sect1.para: Some open items are still to be clarified. For certain questions, a company decision might be needed.

sect2.title: Selection of Topics
sect2.para: Decision about topics to be published as SUSE Best Practices Who decides about relevance of topics/prio list ?

sect2.title: openSUSE
sect2.para: What about openSUSE related topics? Do we officially accept topics for openSUSE? If yes, is it ok to publish them under the brand “SUSE Best Practices”?

sect2.title: Collaboration Platforms
sect2.para: Collaboration space for topic list: Where do we maintain the general list for topics to make sure all stakeholders and decision makers for SUSE Best Practices have access? There are several options: Wiki Etherpad Trello Other (open source tool?)

Collaboration space for writers/subject matter experts: We need to define which platform we use for collaboration with our contributors, no matter if internal or external. For internal projects, we work on GitHub?

sect2.title: Budget
sect2.para: Incentives for contributors: We don´t pay for content contribution, but we’ve got feedback from the field that as a “stimulus”, the key authors/contributors for an SBP should receive a special/limited SUSE Merchandise item In a first step, we have ordered huge plush SUSE Geekos. But we need to decide/define as soon as possible how to proceed after we ran out of stock. Budget for proofreading There is a budget for the translation of documentation, but this budget is calculated only for proofreading and translating the proper product documentation SUSE Best Practices will be published in English, translations are not planned. However, to ensure the quality of the SBP’s regarding proper language, we need to make sure that we will have a budget available for proofreading I have approached our translation coordinator for a quote.

sect2.title: &sbp; Portal
sect2.para: For the &sbp;, we plan to implement a specific portal built for this new series of documents. Currently, the plan is that Tomasz Bazant invests time in the creation of the portal. We still need to discuss the requirements and parameters of the portal.
